The authors continue to discuss the importance of mental models as information-processing structures.

One critical aspect of the Marks et al. (2000) study is that the relationship between shared mental models, team communication quality, and team performance remains a “black box.” While the authors observe a significant relationship of team communication quality with both mental model similarity and team performance, it remains unclear whether communication processes indeed mediated this relationship. For example, it is also possible that shared mental models lead to improved team performance because team members form emotional bonds and have more positive and rewarding experiences during task performance. As a side effect of these affective influences, the team’s communication quality may also improve. In the following section, we highlight how fMRI could help to open this black box by investigating what is actually happening in the neural circuits while participants are playing to pinpoint more precisely the effects that shared mental models have on team communication processes.

sec.title: Benefits From Adding fMRI
sec.p: Communication involves the processing of incoming and outgoing information. Human information-processing capacities are, however, severely limited (e.g., G. A. Miller, 1956). It is of no use to communicate information to individuals who are cognitively overloaded as they lack the capacity to process the information. High-quality team communication that leads to improved team performance requires accordingly a balanced distribution of task-related information among team members to avoid that some team members are cognitively over- or underloaded. Shared mental models allow teams to better predict the resource needs of team members (e.g., Klimoski & Mohammed, 1994; Rouse, Cannon-Bowers, & Salas, 1992). As such, they are better able than teams without shared mental models to estimate the cognitive capabilities and loads of individual team members and distribute information accordingly. One way through which communication processes can mediate the relationship between shared mental models and team performance is, therefore, by balancing the utilization of the limited cognitive resources within the team.

Using fMRI, it is possible to investigate the cognitive processing capacity curves of individual team members while they are engaged in synthetic task environments. One of the biggest advantages of fMRI techniques is that measurement happens exactly at the same moment that a stimulus is processed. Thus, specific communication processes during the game or simulation become intimately linked to neural responses and cognitive processing of the neural stimuli. As already outlined previously, cognitive processes trigger activation in the prefrontal cortex (e.g., E. K. Miller & Cohen, 2001). fMRI observations of activity in the prefrontal cortex provide, therefore, a direct indication of cognitive processing and the related level of cognitive load or working memory utilization.

Previous studies have used brain imaging techniques in a similar way, assessing the impact of cognitive load on information processing. Jansma, Ramsey, Zwart, Gelderen, and Duyn (2007), for example, used fMRI to investigate effortful information processing in a working memory task and demonstrated strong activations in the prefrontal cortex in relation to cognitive effort. Similarly, by including fMRI into their study, Marks et al. (2000) could have measured participants’ cognitive processing capacity curves during communication. If team members of teams with more similar mental models also show more similar activations in the prefrontal cortex during communication (without some members being cognitively over- or underloaded), it can be concluded that they have higher quality communication processes that better balance the team’s limited cognitive resources than other teams communicating under the same conditions. If the former teams also perform better, it can further be concluded that communication processes mediate the relationship between shared mental models and team performance. This would be one way how fMRI could help open the black box between shared mental models and team performance.

Being that we are not aware of previous studies that combined synthetic task environments and fMRI techniques, we believe it is important to think about some of the potential challenges to this combination. First, synthetic task environments are often used to study teams, such as in the example of Marks et al. (2000). In order to study complex team phenomena such as team mental models, it is important to be able to assess cognitive processing of all team members simultaneously. New developments in fMRI techniques allow researchers to assess the cognitive processing of several participants at the same time. Hyperscanning allows the simultaneous fMRI scanning of multiple individuals that are all engaged in the same task. For this, each individual lies in his or her own fMRI tube and the recording of the fMRIs are synchronized. In this way, participants’ brain activation patterns can be recorded simultaneously, while they are all engaged in the same task (Montague et al., 2002).

Second, several types of synthetic task environments require individuals to move around a lot or to physically interact with their team members. In these situations, fMRI might be impractical as participants have to lay almost motionless inside the MRI tube. In these cases, other more portable neuroscience methods such as wireless EEG systems (e.g., Berka et al., 2004) or wearable NIRS systems (Hoshi, 2005) could also be used to measure cognitive processing (Antonenko, Paas, Grabner, & Van Gog, 2010). However, many synthetic task environments that are currently used are in fact computer simulations in which participants use a joystick and talk via a headset with their team members. These kinds of tasks could still be relatively easily accommodated by traditional fMRI techniques.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The goal of the current article is to introduce neuroeconomic research methods to organizational researchers and to demonstrate the benefits that a combined experimental/neuroscience approach can have for theory development, testing, pruning, and the development of new research directions. It is important to note that we are not trying to sell this approach as the magic bullet. Rather, we would like to offer it as an approach that can provide one important piece to the puzzle. We believe that research questions should be illuminated using different methodologies and that triangulation of research methods can help researchers develop a more complete picture of the relationships between variables. Using neuroeconomics provides one important angle for researchers to better understand the underlying motivational and cognitive processes behind observable behavior. This in turn can have great benefits for gaining a deeper understanding of our constructs of interest and for building better theories.

The current article tries to demonstrate the advantages of neuroeconomics and the potential insights that can be gained from applying it to organizational research questions. We introduced four common economic game/neuroscience combinations and explored how they could improve current organizational research. We also discussed how neuroscience methods could be applied to synthetic task environments, a more commonly used organizational research method. In the following, we want to discuss the specific strengths inherent in using a combination of experimental design and neuroscience. We then discuss some limitations of this approach and how they might be overcome. We conclude with a discussion of the implications this approach might have for future applications of neuroeconomic techniques to organizational studies.

sec.title: Strengths of This Approach
sec.p: We believe that the core strength of neuroeconomics is that it provides the opportunity to open up the black box of mental processes behind a given observable behavior. The fact that neuroeconomics pairs neuroscience methods with specific, well-developed experimental designs allows researchers to isolate behaviors and to then explore the neural substrates of these behaviors. With the experimental design, researchers can first infer causality between variables and then determine why and how participants chose to respond in a particular way. More importantly, this method can help break down the mental processes that led to a given behavior. This can aid researchers to draw conclusion regarding why participants act in certain ways in a given situation. We believe that answering the why question is the core purpose of organizational research.

In their 2000 work, Kozlowski and Klein argue:
Many phenomena in organizations have their theoretical foundation in the cognition, affect, behavior, and characteristics of individuals, which—through social interaction, exchange, and amplification—have emergent properties that manifest at higher levels. In other words, many collective constructs represent the aggregate influence of individuals. (p. 15) Following this line of thought, it seems even more important to understand the micro-level foundations of behaviors, cognitions, and affect. Individual-level constructs form the basis of higher level constructs and processes that emerge in organizations. These higher-level constructs can only be fully understood, if we can understand the constructs at the micro level.

Part of the purpose of understanding the underlying motivational and cognitive processes of individual behaviors is to build better, more accurate theories. The field of organizational research has seen a recent increase in calls for better theory development and testing, bemoaning a lack of real understanding of the processes underlying behaviors and a lack of rigor when it comes to theory testing (e.g., Edwards, 2010; Leavitt et al., 2010). As Edwards (2010) put it:
In the interest of theory development, management and organizational research would make better progress if we devoted more attention to theoretical refinement, conducting research that identifies the boundaries and limitations of theories, stages competitive tests between rival theories, and increases the precision of theories so they yield strong predictions that can be falsified. (p. 615) Along these lines, W. J. Becker et al. (2011) argue that neuroscience techniques can be especially helpful in uncovering underlying processes and aid in developing better theories. It can further assist in testing competing theories against each other by providing an alternative lens for assessing the underlying processes of observed behaviors. We believe that neuroeconomics goes even one step further. Coupling the experimental design with neuroscience techniques, it can offer method triangulation to test theories in multiple ways and test the reliability of our conclusions across multiple methods. We believe that triangulation is currently undervalued and underutilized in organizational research.

sec.title: External validity
sec.p: Despite the promises of the neuroeconomic research approach, it is also important to recognize and understand its limitations. Neuroeconomics suffers from the general limitations common to all experimental laboratory research. In this context, organizational researchers are typically most concerned that laboratory research may not easily generalize to the “real world” (Highhouse, 2009). While we acknowledge that external validity is not a particular strength of laboratory experiments, we hold that there is convincing empirical evidence suggesting that findings from lab-based studies will generalize to field settings. In several meta-analyses investigating the correspondence between lab-based and field-based effect sizes it was demonstrated that laboratory research achieves a high degree of external validity. Anderson, Lindsay, and Bushman (1999), for example, aggregated the results of 38 different meta-analyses and observed a .73 correlation between lab effect sizes and field effect sizes of conceptually similar variables.

Furthermore, generalizability involves an understanding of the processes underlying outcomes. Two quotes demonstrate how this applies to neuroeconomics. Citing Shapiro (2002), Highhouse (2009) argues that “the ability to generalize from one situation to another requires an understanding of underlying principles and recognizing which principles apply in which situations” (p. 556). W. J. Becker et al. (2011) point out that “neural mechanisms are largely homogenous across all individuals and are recruited to respond to numerous different organizational situations. That is to say, each neuron operates in the same way, and all brains are organized in a similar fashion” (p. 936). Neuroeconomics provides us with an understanding of the neural principles underlying various economic behaviors that are likely to apply in a similar way across different situations. As such, neuroeconomics fulfills the requirements for generalizability stipulated by Highhouse (2009). In this context it is also important to reiterate that external validity should be established by method triangulation and, hence, assessed across a range of studies on the same topic (e.g., Colquitt, 2008; Cook & Campbell, 1979; Shadish, Cook, & Campbell, 2002). For a more comprehensive discussion of the external validity of laboratory experiments in organizational research, see Colquitt (2008), Highhouse (2009), and Moore and Flynn (2008).

sec.title: Reverse inference
sec.p: Neuroeconomics research using brain imaging techniques such as fMRI also suffers from a problem of reverse inference, a general limitation common to most brain imaging research (e.g., Aguirre & D’Esposito, 1999; Poldrack, 2006). The reverse inference problem arises when one brain imaging study shows that a mental process such as fear leads to activations in brain region X and a later study that observes activations in brain region X concludes that the subject experiences fear. However, brain regions can support different mental processes. Activations in brain region X can indicate fear but also other mental process associated with this region.

The reverse inference practice becomes increasingly problematic when inferences are drawn about very specific mental processes such as specific emotions. It is a comparatively lesser problem when less specific processes such as emotions in general are considered. Take, for example, the question whether a specific task is related to increased emotional or cognitive processing. Increased activity in the limbic system (the emotional center of the brain) during the performance of the task would suggest that the task involves increased emotional processing. The competing hypothesis, namely, that the task involves increased cognitive processing, is very unlikely related to increased activity in the emotional center of the brain. Reverse inference is therefore relatively unproblematic in this example.

Reverse inference would be more problematic when drawing conclusions about the different emotional processes involved in the task. The relevant processes are likely to activate the same or closely connected structures in the brain’s emotional center, making inferences to a specific process difficult. Thus, in order to correctly apply reverse inference, it is required to have an understanding of the extent to which the source of inference (i.e., the brain activation pattern) could potentially reflect different mental processes and to what degree the different mental processes are relevant for the research question at hand (see also Cacioppo et al., 2003).

Like any research method, reverse inference is most valid within the right context. It is best used in the context of a stream of research, as a first step for generating hypotheses and ideas that are then tested in follow-up studies. Poldrack and Wagner (2004) concluded, therefore, that:
The reverse-inference approach is strongest when it is used not as an ad hoc means to explain the occurrence of particular activations in a single study, but rather as a tool to drive hypotheses that are then tested in subsequent experiments. (p. 180) In conclusion, both with reference to external validity and reverse inference, it is important to recognize that neuroeconomics must be embedded in a broader research stream, complemented by traditional organizational research methods (see also W. J. Becker & Cropanzano, 2010).

sec.title: Costs and practicality
sec.p: A general drawback of fMRI is the high costs involved in purchasing, maintaining, and using fMRI scanners. In particular, the high costs per hour of use make it difficult to achieve the large sample sizes that are conventional in organizational research. While research has shown that the statistical power of fMRI data is relatively robust with small participant numbers (e.g., Friston, Holmes, & Worsley, 1999), even these small sample studies can be quite expensive (for a discussion of the required number of participants in an fMRI study, see Desmond & Glover, 2002; Murphy & Garavan, 2004).

Another drawback of fMRI is the restrictions of the scanner tube that requires participants to remain almost motionless in a supine position and, hence, constrains the kind of tasks that can be used in combination with fMRI. If costs and practicality of fMRI are of concern, there are a number of alternative brain imaging techniques available. While these techniques are generally inferior to fMRI in terms of spatial resolution, their employment requires less administrative and monetary effort.

One of these alternatives is electroencephalography (EEG). This method uses electrodes placed at specified locations on the scalp to measure electrical activity that results from neurons firing in the brain during brain activity. Given that EEG allows participants to sit upright while being investigated, the method is easier to use, but also less expensive and more portable than fMRI. The most important disadvantage of EEG is a relatively low spatial resolution resulting from a large number of possible configurations of brain sources that can cause the measured electrical activity at the scalp. An exemplary study that used EEG to study topics of relevance to business research comes from Hannah, Balthazard, Waldman, and Jennings (2008). They used EEG technology to investigate how individual differences in cognition and affect are related to leadership performance and effectiveness.

Magnetoencephalography (MEG) is a complementary method to EEG that also uses sensors arranged on the surface of the head (fixed in a helmet design) to measure brain activity. MEG measures changes in the magnetic field below the scalp that are associated with changes in the electrical field during brain activity. The spatial resolution of MEG and EEG is very similar. Yet, MEG is more sensitive to activity in deeper brain regions than EEG, but also more expensive and less portable. MEG has, for example, been used by Ambler, Braeutigam, Stins, Rose, and Swithenby (2004) to investigate how consumers make buying decisions.

While EEG and MEG analyze electromagnetic activity of the brain, near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) measures changes in cerebral blood oxygenation to examine the activation of different brain areas. Similar to fMRI, NIRS exploits the fact that a local increase in neural activity leads to an increased flow of oxygenated blood to the involved brain region. NIRS uses near-infrared light from light sources placed on the scalp to measure the absorption and scatter of that light by the skull and underlying cortical tissue, which depends on the level of cerebral blood oxygenation. In comparison to fMRI, NIRS measurement devices are smaller, more portable, less obtrusive, and less expensive to purchase and maintain. The spatial resolution of NIRS is, however, relatively poor compared to fMRI. An example of how NIRS can be used in business research comes from Lin, Tuan, and Chiu (2010), who explored the neural correlates of consumer preferences for product brands.

sec.title: Other limitations
sec.p: In addition to the previous points, there are a number of other limitations that should be mentioned here. For example, Powell (2011) discussed the mereological fallacy problem (M. R. Bennett & Hacker, 2003), the problem inherent in focusing exclusively on the human brain and ascribing activities such as thinking, feeling, and believing that result from the interactions of different parts of the human body to a single organ. He also pointed to critics lamenting implausibly high correlations resulting from flawed data analysis techniques employed in social neuroscience (Vul, Harris, Winkielman, & Pashler, 2009).

A similar critique of the statistical techniques used to interpret fMRI data comes from C. Bennett, Miller, and Wolford (2009), who demonstrated that random noise and uncorrected statistical thresholds can lead to ridiculous fMRI results. These researchers scanned the brain of a dead Atlantic salmon while showing it photographs of humans in different social situations. They observed evidence of neural activity in the dead fish’s brain in response to the pictures, a result that is of course a statistical artifact that could have been avoided by using more conservative forms of correction.

Furthermore, related to the previous discussion of external validity, one might question how far brain activity during fMRI scans that require participants to lay almost motionless inside a MRI tube resembles the brain activity of human participants in organizational settings. As one reviewer put it: “I wonder to what extent research using these methods in lab contexts would generate results that could not hold in the field, in which sometimes the decision maker, within the work context, reviews information on the computer, paces the office, gesticulates when thinking about consequences of the possible decisions, choices, etc., etc.” This is an interesting point that applies to all research that attempts to employ neuroscience techniques to address questions in business research, including neuromarketing (Ariely & Berns, 2010), neurostrategy (Powell, 2011), and organizational neuroscience (W. J. Becker et al., 2011). This critique could be addressed in the future by comparing fMRI results to findings from more portable brain imaging techniques that allow participants to move around such as wearable NIRS systems (Hoshi, 2005) or wireless EEG systems (e.g., Berka et al., 2004).

In conclusion, as with any research method, there are limitations associated with neuroscience and neuroeconomics. Some of these, including those related to data analysis techniques, will certainly be resolved in the future. Others, such as general concerns about external validity, will remain. Powell (2011), therefore, concluded that “in the short run, neuroscience will continue to ride a steep growth curve in the social sciences, and its long run contributions will be assessed on a timescale of decades” (p. 1491). Overall, given the evidence regarding the utility of this approach, we believe that the benefits outweigh the costs.

sec.title: Implications for Future Research
sec.p: How can neuroeconomics be effectively integrated into organizational research? As a first step, organizational researchers can build on the large number of existing neuroeconomics studies and apply their findings to topics of relevance to organizational research. Take, for example, Solnick and Schweitzer’s (1999) study of the beauty premium. The controversy surrounding the two most prominent explanations for the beauty premium, namely, the physical attractiveness stereotype and taste-based discrimination, could have been illuminated with existing neuroscience evidence indicating that the brain’s reward system is active while people look at attractive persons (Aharon et al., 2001). This approach mirrors W. J. Becker et al.’s (2011) recommendation “that everyone keep abreast of the findings and themes emerging from basic neuroscience research and consider how these might influence and inform their own research” (p. 951). Similarly Powell (2011) argued from a strategic management point of view that “behavioral neuroscience has left a large trove of neural evidence to be mined for insights in strategic management, and neuroeconomics in particular has acted as a silent benefactor to behavioral strategy” (p. 1491). He also warned that “researchers who do not keep informed of developments in behavioral neuroscience will find themselves facing theoretical claims and empirical data they do not understand” (p. 1491).

As a next step, organizational researchers should consider applying neuroeconomics methods in their own research. Some organizational scholars have already employed economic games to study their topic of interest, as the previous examples demonstrate. The next challenge will be to combine economic games with neuroscience methods for more rigorous theory testing and the development of new theories. The technical sophistication of many neuroscience methods can best be overcome by collaborations with experienced neuroscientists and neuroeconomists. Powell (2011) recommends building relationships with researchers from these disciplines to develop joint research agendas. He suggests that “these relationships will lead to arrangements such as collaboratively funded research projects, joint research seminars, and joint doctoral scholarships” (p. 1495). Ultimately, organizational researchers face the same challenges as economists did when they began to incorporate neuroscience into their research. Economists have met this challenge remarkably well and benefited greatly from this new research perspective. This article concludes, therefore, by encouraging organizational researchers to venture into this novel field of research. The potential gains of such efforts promise to be substantial.
